topic_name: Classification of Elements and Periodicity in Properties

canonical_explanation.text: The classification of elements has evolved over centuries. Dobereiner's triads grouped elements into sets of three where the atomic weight of the middle element was approximately the average of the other two (e.g., Li-Na-K, Ca-Sr-Ba). Newlands' law of octaves arranged elements by increasing atomic weight and noted that every eighth element had similar properties — this worked only up to calcium. Mendeleev's periodic table arranged elements by increasing atomic mass and grouped them by similar chemical properties, leaving gaps for undiscovered elements (eka-boron, eka-aluminium, eka-silicon). The modern periodic law (Moseley, 1913) states that the physical and chemical properties of elements are a periodic function of their atomic numbers. The modern periodic table has 18 groups and 7 periods. Groups 1-2 are s-block, groups 13-18 are p-block, groups 3-12 are d-block, and the lanthanides and actinides form the f-block. Elements are classified as metals, non-metals, and metalloids (semi-metals). Atomic radius generally decreases across a period (increasing nuclear charge with same principal shell) and increases down a group (addition of new shells). Ionic radius: cations are smaller than parent atoms, anions are larger. Ionisation enthalpy (IE) is the energy required to remove the most loosely bound electron from an isolated gaseous atom. IE generally increases across a period and decreases down a group. Electron gain enthalpy (EGE) is the enthalpy change when an electron is added to an isolated gaseous atom. Halogens have the most negative EGE (most exothermic); noble gases have positive EGE. Electronegativity (Pauling scale) increases across a period and decreases down a group; fluorine is the most electronegative element. Metallic character decreases across a period and increases down a group. Anomalous properties arise in the second period due to small size, high electronegativity, absence of d orbitals, and the ability to form pπ-pπ multiple bonds (e.g., N₂ has a triple bond, O₂ has a double bond, while P and S form single bonds in their allotropes).
rules: Modern periodic law: properties are periodic functions of atomic number.
Periodic table: 7 periods, 18 groups; s-block (groups 1-2), p-block (groups 13-18), d-block (groups 3-12), f-block (lanthanides, actinides).
Atomic radius decreases across a period (left to right) and increases down a group.
Ionic radii: cation < parent atom; anion > parent atom. Isoelectronic species: larger nuclear charge = smaller radius.
Ionisation enthalpy increases across a period and decreases down a group.
Extra stability of half-filled (p³, d⁵) and fully filled (p⁶, d¹⁰) subshells causes higher IE than expected.
Electron gain enthalpy becomes more negative across a period; halogens have the most negative EGE.
Electronegativity increases across a period and decreases down a group (Pauling scale).
Metallic character decreases across a period and increases down a group.
Second-period elements show anomalous behaviour due to small size, absence of d orbitals, and pπ-pπ bond formation.
Diagonal relationship: Li~Mg, Be~Al, B~Si show similarities in properties due to comparable charge density.

questions.question_text: Dobereiner's classification of elements was based on grouping elements into:
questions.explanation_correct: Dobereiner grouped elements into triads (sets of three) where the atomic weight of the middle element was approximately the average of the other two. Examples include Li-Na-K and Ca-Sr-Ba.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Pairs is not a classification method. Octaves was Newlands' arrangement. Periods are part of the modern periodic table structure.

questions.question_text: Newlands' Law of Octaves was limited because it was applicable only up to the element:
questions.explanation_correct: Newlands' Law of Octaves stated that every eighth element had similar properties when arranged by increasing atomic weight. However, this pattern held only up to calcium (atomic weight ~40) and failed for heavier elements.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The law worked well for lighter elements but broke down after calcium. Sodium and potassium are too early, and iron is beyond where the law failed.

questions.question_text: Mendeleev arranged elements in his periodic table in order of increasing:
questions.explanation_correct: Mendeleev arranged elements in order of increasing atomic mass and grouped elements with similar chemical properties together. He left gaps for undiscovered elements and predicted their properties.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Atomic number was used by Moseley in the modern periodic law. Electronegativity and electron affinity are properties, not the basis for Mendeleev's arrangement.

questions.question_text: Mendeleev predicted the existence of an element he called eka-aluminium, which was later discovered as:
questions.explanation_correct: Mendeleev's eka-aluminium was later discovered as gallium (Ga, discovered by Lecoq de Boisbaudran in 1875). Its properties closely matched Mendeleev's predictions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Scandium corresponds to eka-boron. Germanium corresponds to eka-silicon. Titanium was already known during Mendeleev's time.

questions.question_text: A major defect of Mendeleev's periodic table was:

options.text: The position of hydrogen was ambiguous

questions.explanation_correct: Hydrogen could be placed either in Group I (with alkali metals, as it forms H⁺) or in Group VII (with halogens, as it forms H⁻ and exists as a diatomic molecule). This ambiguity was a major defect of Mendeleev's table.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Noble gases were not known then and were later accommodated as Group 0. Transition elements were included. Isotopes were an issue but hydrogen's position was the most prominent defect.

questions.question_text: The anomalous pair of elements in Mendeleev's periodic table where the heavier element was placed before the lighter one is:
questions.explanation_correct: Tellurium (atomic mass 127.6) was placed before iodine (atomic mass 126.9) by Mendeleev to keep them in groups consistent with their chemical properties. This violated the increasing atomic mass order and was an anomaly.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Na-Mg, O-F, and S-Cl follow the normal order of increasing atomic mass. The Te-I pair and Co-Ni pair were the anomalous reversals.

questions.question_text: The modern periodic law, which uses atomic number as the basis for classification, was proposed by:
questions.explanation_correct: Henry Moseley (1913) established through X-ray spectroscopy that atomic number (not atomic mass) is the fundamental property of an element. The modern periodic law states: properties of elements are a periodic function of their atomic numbers.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mendeleev used atomic mass. Newlands used atomic weight for octaves. Dobereiner used atomic weight for triads.

questions.question_text: The modern periodic table has:
questions.explanation_correct: The modern (long form) periodic table has 18 vertical groups (columns) and 7 horizontal periods (rows). Groups are numbered 1 to 18 using IUPAC nomenclature.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mendeleev's table had 8 groups but the modern table has 18. There are only 7 periods (corresponding to filling of the 1st through 7th shells).

questions.question_text: Elements of groups 1 and 2 belong to the:
questions.explanation_correct: Groups 1 (alkali metals) and 2 (alkaline earth metals) belong to the s-block because their outermost electrons enter the s orbital. Their general configuration is ns¹ (Group 1) and ns² (Group 2).
questions.explanation_incorrect: p-block contains groups 13-18. d-block contains groups 3-12. f-block includes the lanthanides and actinides.

questions.question_text: The longest period in the periodic table is:
questions.explanation_correct: The sixth period is the longest with 32 elements (2 in s-block + 10 in d-block + 14 in f-block lanthanides + 6 in p-block). The seventh period also has 32 elements but is incomplete with naturally occurring elements.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The second period has 8 elements, the third has 8, and the fifth has 18. The sixth period has 32, making it the longest.

questions.question_text: An element has the configuration [Ne] 3s² 3p⁴. It belongs to:
questions.explanation_correct: The outermost shell is n = 3, so it is in Period 3. Total valence electrons in the outermost shell = 2 (3s) + 4 (3p) = 6. For p-block elements, group number = 10 + (s + p electrons) = 10 + 6 = 16. This element is sulphur.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Group 14 would require 4 valence electrons. Period 2 has outermost shell n = 2. The configuration clearly shows n = 3 and 6 valence electrons, placing it in Group 16, Period 3.

questions.question_text: Which of the following elements is a metalloid?
questions.explanation_correct: Silicon is a metalloid (semi-metal). Metalloids have properties intermediate between metals and non-metals. Silicon is a semiconductor and is found along the diagonal staircase line in the periodic table.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Phosphorus and sulphur are non-metals. Aluminium is a metal. Silicon, germanium, arsenic, antimony, and tellurium are common metalloids.

questions.question_text: The d-block elements are also called:
questions.explanation_correct: The d-block elements (groups 3-12) are called transition elements because they represent a transition from the highly electropositive s-block metals to the less electropositive p-block elements.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Representative elements are s- and p-block elements. Inner transition elements are f-block (lanthanides and actinides). Noble gases are Group 18 p-block elements.

questions.question_text: An element with atomic number 37 belongs to:
questions.explanation_correct: Z = 37: [Kr] 5s¹. The last electron enters the 5s orbital, so it is in Period 5 and Group 1. This element is rubidium (Rb), an alkali metal.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Group 2 would require configuration ending in s². Period 4 would have outermost shell n = 4. Group 17 would need a p⁵ configuration.

questions.question_text: Across a period (left to right), the atomic radius generally:
questions.explanation_correct: Across a period, the atomic radius decreases because the nuclear charge increases while electrons are added to the same principal shell. The increased effective nuclear charge pulls the electron cloud closer to the nucleus.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Atomic radius does not increase, remain constant, or show a mixed trend across a period. The steady increase in Zeff with each additional proton causes a consistent decrease.

questions.question_text: Down a group, the atomic radius generally:
questions.explanation_correct: Down a group, the atomic radius increases because a new principal energy level (shell) is added with each period. The increased shielding effect outweighs the increase in nuclear charge, so the outermost electrons are farther from the nucleus.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The addition of new shells dominates over the increase in nuclear charge, so radius increases, not decreases.

questions.question_text: Ionisation enthalpy is the energy required to:

options.text: Add an electron to a gaseous atom
Remove the most loosely bound electron from an isolated gaseous atom

questions.explanation_correct: Ionisation enthalpy (IE) is the minimum energy required to remove the most loosely bound electron from an isolated gaseous atom in its ground state to form a cation: M(g) → M⁺(g) + e⁻.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Adding an electron relates to electron gain enthalpy. Breaking a bond relates to bond dissociation energy. Melting a solid relates to enthalpy of fusion.

questions.question_text: Among the elements of Period 2, which has the highest first ionisation enthalpy?
questions.explanation_correct: Neon, being a noble gas with a completely filled electronic configuration (1s² 2s² 2p⁶), has the highest first ionisation enthalpy in Period 2. Noble gases have exceptionally stable configurations.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ionisation enthalpy generally increases across a period. Neon, at the far right, has the highest IE. Lithium has the lowest IE in Period 2.

questions.question_text: The first ionisation enthalpy of nitrogen is higher than that of oxygen because:

options.text: Nitrogen has a larger atomic radius
Nitrogen has a half-filled 2p subshell which is extra stable

questions.explanation_correct: Nitrogen (1s² 2s² 2p³) has a half-filled 2p subshell, which has extra stability due to symmetrical electron distribution and exchange energy. Removing an electron from this stable configuration requires more energy than removing one from oxygen's 2p⁴ configuration, where one orbital has a paired electron experiencing repulsion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Nitrogen has a smaller radius than oxygen. While oxygen is more electronegative, that doesn't explain this IE anomaly. Having more protons would raise IE, but nitrogen has fewer protons (7 vs 8). The anomaly is due to extra stability of the half-filled subshell.

questions.question_text: The first ionisation enthalpy of Be is higher than that of B because:

options.text: Be has a higher atomic number
Be has a fully filled 2s subshell which is extra stable
B has a higher electron affinity

questions.explanation_correct: Beryllium (1s² 2s²) has a fully filled 2s subshell, giving it extra stability. Boron (1s² 2s² 2p¹) must lose an electron from the higher-energy 2p orbital, which is easier to remove. This is why IE₁(Be) > IE₁(B), an anomaly in the otherwise increasing trend.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Be has a lower atomic number (4 vs 5). While Be is smaller, the key reason is the extra stability of the filled 2s subshell. Electron affinity of B is not the relevant factor.

questions.question_text: Among the isoelectronic species Na⁺, Mg²⁺, F⁻, and O²⁻ (all with 10 electrons), the smallest ionic radius belongs to:
questions.explanation_correct: In isoelectronic species (same number of electrons), the species with the highest nuclear charge has the smallest radius. Mg²⁺ has 12 protons pulling on 10 electrons, giving it the strongest Zeff and therefore the smallest radius. Order: Mg²⁺ < Na⁺ < F⁻ < O²⁻.
questions.explanation_incorrect: O²⁻ has the largest radius (8 protons, 10 electrons). F⁻ has 9 protons. Na⁺ has 11 protons. Mg²⁺ has 12 protons, giving it the strongest pull and smallest radius.

questions.question_text: The electron gain enthalpy is most negative for:
questions.explanation_correct: Halogens (Group 17) have the most negative electron gain enthalpy because they need only one electron to achieve a noble gas configuration. Chlorine has the most negative electron gain enthalpy (−349 kJ/mol) among all elements.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Noble gases have positive EGE (they resist gaining electrons). Alkaline earth metals have stable ns² configuration, making EGE less negative. Alkali metals have less negative EGE than halogens.

questions.question_text: The electron gain enthalpy of chlorine is more negative than that of fluorine because:

options.text: Chlorine has a larger atomic size, reducing electron-electron repulsion in the outer shell

questions.explanation_correct: Despite fluorine being smaller and more electronegative, its very small 2p orbitals create strong electron-electron repulsion when an extra electron is added. Chlorine's larger 3p orbitals accommodate the extra electron with less repulsion, making its EGE more negative (−349 kJ/mol vs −328 kJ/mol for F).
questions.explanation_incorrect: More protons alone don't determine EGE. Higher electronegativity of F would suggest more negative EGE, but the small size effect dominates. d-orbital availability is not the primary factor here.

questions.question_text: Which of the following has a positive electron gain enthalpy?
questions.explanation_correct: Noble gases like neon have completely filled electron configurations (stable octets) and do not tend to accept additional electrons. Adding an electron to neon would require energy, making its electron gain enthalpy positive.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Chlorine (−349 kJ/mol), oxygen (−141 kJ/mol), and fluorine (−328 kJ/mol) all have negative electron gain enthalpies, meaning energy is released when they gain an electron.

questions.question_text: The second ionisation enthalpy of Na is much higher than its first ionisation enthalpy because:

options.text: Na has a large atomic radius
The second electron is removed from a stable noble gas core (2,8 configuration)

questions.explanation_correct: After removing the first electron, Na⁺ has the configuration 1s² 2s² 2p⁶ (same as neon, a noble gas core). Removing a second electron from this very stable configuration requires enormously more energy, making IE₂ >> IE₁.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Large atomic radius, low electronegativity, and metallic nature do not explain the specific jump between IE₁ and IE₂. The critical factor is removing an electron from a stable noble gas core.

questions.question_text: Electronegativity of elements generally increases:

options.text: Across a period from left to right
From right to left across a period
Electronegativity remains constant across a period

questions.explanation_correct: Electronegativity increases across a period from left to right because atomic size decreases and nuclear charge increases, leading to a stronger attraction for shared electrons. It decreases down a group as atomic size increases.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Electronegativity decreases down a group, not increases. It does not remain constant. It increases from left to right, not right to left.

questions.question_text: The most electronegative element in the periodic table is:
questions.explanation_correct: Fluorine is the most electronegative element with a Pauling electronegativity value of 4.0. It has the smallest atomic size among halogens and strongly attracts shared electrons.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Oxygen (3.5), chlorine (3.0), and nitrogen (3.0) are all less electronegative than fluorine (4.0). Fluorine's small size and high nuclear charge give it the highest electronegativity.

questions.question_text: On the Pauling scale, the electronegativity of fluorine is:
questions.explanation_correct: On the Pauling electronegativity scale, fluorine has the highest value of 4.0. This scale ranges from about 0.7 (for caesium and francium) to 4.0 (for fluorine).
questions.explanation_incorrect: 2.5 is approximately the electronegativity of carbon. 3.0 is approximately for nitrogen and chlorine. 3.5 is for oxygen. Fluorine is 4.0.

questions.question_text: Electronegativity is not a periodic property in the strict sense because it:

options.text: Depends on the bonding environment and is not an inherent atomic property
Is the same for all elements

questions.explanation_correct: Electronegativity is not a strictly measurable atomic property like IE or EGE. It depends on the bonding situation — the same atom can show different electronegativities depending on its hybridisation state and the nature of the bonded atom. It is a relative measure, not an absolute one.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Electronegativity can be estimated (though not directly measured like IE). It varies across elements. It applies to both metals and non-metals.

questions.question_text: Among Li, Na, K, and Rb, which has the highest electronegativity?
questions.explanation_correct: Electronegativity decreases down a group. Li, being at the top of Group 1, has the smallest atomic size and the highest electronegativity (1.0 on the Pauling scale) among alkali metals.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Electronegativity decreases as Li > Na > K > Rb due to increasing atomic size down the group. Rb has the lowest electronegativity among these.

questions.question_text: A large difference in electronegativity between two bonded atoms leads to:
questions.explanation_correct: A large electronegativity difference (typically > 1.7 on the Pauling scale) between two atoms leads to ionic bonding, as the more electronegative atom essentially takes the electron from the less electronegative atom. For example, NaCl (EN difference = 2.1) is ionic.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A purely covalent bond requires zero or very small EN difference. A metallic bond occurs between metal atoms. A coordinate bond involves donation of a lone pair.

questions.question_text: The correct order of electronegativity is:
questions.explanation_correct: Electronegativity decreases down a group: F (4.0) > Cl (3.0) > Br (2.8) > I (2.5). This is because atomic size increases down the group, and the bonding electrons are farther from the nucleus.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The order strictly follows the group trend: F > Cl > Br > I. No reversal occurs in the halogen group's electronegativity trend.

questions.question_text: Metallic character of elements across a period (left to right):
questions.explanation_correct: Metallic character decreases across a period from left to right because ionisation enthalpy increases, making it harder for atoms to lose electrons. Elements on the left are metals, while those on the right are non-metals.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The increasing nuclear charge across a period makes it progressively harder to lose electrons, reducing metallic character steadily from left to right.

questions.question_text: The oxide of a highly electropositive element is expected to be:
questions.explanation_correct: Highly electropositive elements (metals) form basic oxides. For example, Na₂O and CaO are basic because they react with water to form hydroxides (NaOH, Ca(OH)₂). The basicity of oxides increases with metallic character.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Acidic oxides are formed by non-metals (e.g., SO₃, P₂O₅). Amphoteric oxides are formed by elements like Al, Zn, and Pb. Neutral oxides (e.g., CO, NO) are relatively rare.

questions.question_text: Across a period, the nature of oxides changes from:
questions.explanation_correct: Across a period (left to right), the nature of oxides changes from basic (Na₂O, MgO) to amphoteric (Al₂O₃) to acidic (SiO₂, P₂O₅, SO₃, Cl₂O₇). This correlates with the decrease in metallic character.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The order is basic → amphoteric → acidic, not the reverse. As metallic character decreases across a period, oxides become less basic and more acidic.

questions.question_text: Among Na₂O, MgO, Al₂O₃, and SiO₂, the amphoteric oxide is:
questions.explanation_correct: Al₂O₃ is amphoteric — it reacts with both acids and bases. It reacts with HCl to form AlCl₃ and with NaOH to form NaAlO₂. This is because aluminium is on the border between metals and non-metals.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Na₂O is strongly basic. MgO is basic. SiO₂ is acidic. Al₂O₃ is the only amphoteric oxide among these.

questions.question_text: The diagonal relationship in the periodic table exists between:
questions.explanation_correct: Lithium and magnesium show a diagonal relationship — they have similar properties despite being in different groups and periods. This is because they have similar charge density (charge-to-radius ratio). Other diagonal pairs include Be~Al and B~Si.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Li and Na are in the same group, not diagonal. Na and Mg are in the same period. Be and B are in the same period. Diagonal relationships exist between elements diagonally placed: Li~Mg, Be~Al, B~Si.

questions.question_text: Second-period elements show anomalous behaviour compared to other members of their group primarily because of:

options.text: Their small size, high electronegativity, and absence of d orbitals

questions.explanation_correct: Second-period elements (Li to Ne) show anomalous behaviour due to their small atomic size, high electronegativity, high charge density, and absence of d orbitals (which limits their coordination number and prevents expansion of the octet). They can also form strong pπ-pπ multiple bonds.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Second-period elements have low atomic mass, not high. They have relatively high IE, not low. A filled s subshell is not unique to the second period.

questions.question_text: Nitrogen forms N₂ with a triple bond, whereas phosphorus forms P₄ with single bonds. This difference is because:

options.text: Nitrogen has small size and can form effective pπ-pπ multiple bonds

questions.explanation_correct: Nitrogen's small atomic size allows effective lateral overlap of 2p orbitals to form strong pπ-pπ bonds (triple bond in N₂). Phosphorus, being larger, has poor 3p-3p overlap and prefers to form single P-P bonds in P₄ (tetrahedral structure).
questions.explanation_incorrect: While nitrogen is more electronegative, the key factor is the ability to form effective pπ-pπ bonds due to small size. Phosphorus has lower IE than nitrogen. Phosphorus does have lone pairs.

questions.question_text: Which of the following properties does NOT show a regular trend across a period?
questions.explanation_correct: Electron gain enthalpy does not show a smooth regular trend across a period. There are anomalies due to extra stability of half-filled and fully filled subshells (e.g., nitrogen has less negative EGE than carbon, and noble gases have positive EGE).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Atomic radius decreases regularly. Valency first increases from 1 to 4 then decreases from 4 to 0. Metallic character decreases regularly. EGE has several irregularities.

questions.question_text: A cation is always _______ than/as its parent atom.
questions.explanation_correct: A cation is always smaller than its parent atom because the removal of electrons reduces electron-electron repulsion and the same nuclear charge pulls the remaining electrons more tightly. Also, if the outermost shell is emptied, the ion has fewer shells.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cations are never larger than or the same size as their parent atoms. The loss of electrons always results in a decrease in ionic radius.

questions.question_text: The correct order of atomic radii is:
questions.explanation_correct: These elements are in Period 3. Atomic radius decreases across a period from left to right: Na (186 pm) > Mg (160 pm) > Al (143 pm) > Si (117 pm) due to increasing effective nuclear charge.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Atomic radius decreases left to right across a period. Na, being furthest left in Period 3 among these elements, has the largest radius.

questions.question_text: An element with Z = 56 belongs to which block of the periodic table?
questions.explanation_correct: Z = 56 is barium (Ba). Its configuration is [Xe] 6s². The last electron enters the 6s orbital, placing it in the s-block (Group 2, Period 6).
questions.explanation_incorrect: With configuration [Xe] 6s², the outermost electron is in an s orbital, not p, d, or f. Barium is an alkaline earth metal in the s-block.

questions.question_text: The IE₁ of alkali metals follows the order:
questions.explanation_correct: Down Group 1, ionisation enthalpy decreases because atomic size increases, and the outermost electron is farther from the nucleus and more shielded. So IE₁: Li > Na > K > Rb > Cs.
questions.explanation_incorrect: IE₁ decreases down the group, not increases. Li has the highest IE₁ because it is the smallest alkali metal. Cs has the lowest.

questions.question_text: The maximum oxidation state of chlorine in its oxoacids is:
questions.explanation_correct: Chlorine can show a maximum oxidation state of +7, as in perchloric acid (HClO₄). This is because chlorine has 7 valence electrons and can expand its octet using vacant 3d orbitals. The oxoacids of chlorine are: HClO (+1), HClO₂ (+3), HClO₃ (+5), HClO₄ (+7).
questions.explanation_incorrect: +3 is seen in HClO₂, +5 in HClO₃, and +1 in HClO, but the maximum oxidation state is +7 in HClO₄.

questions.question_text: Which of the following has the largest atomic radius?
questions.explanation_correct: N, P, As, and Bi are all in Group 15. Atomic radius increases down the group as new shells are added. Bi, being at the bottom, has the largest atomic radius.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Atomic radius increases down a group: N < P < As < Sb < Bi. Nitrogen, being at the top, has the smallest radius.

questions.question_text: The element with configuration [Kr] 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p³ would be expected to form an oxide with the formula:
questions.explanation_correct: This element is in Group 15 (5 valence electrons: 5s² 5p³). Group 15 elements typically form oxides of the type X₂O₃ (with +3 state) and X₂O₅ (with +5 state). The highest oxide is X₂O₅ (e.g., Sb₂O₅).
questions.explanation_incorrect: X₂O₃ is also possible but X₂O₅ represents the highest oxide. XO₂ and XO₃ don't match the typical oxide formulae for Group 15 elements.

questions.question_text: In Dobereiner's triad of Li (7), Na (23), and K (39), the atomic mass of the middle element Na should be approximately:
questions.explanation_correct: In Dobereiner's triad, the atomic mass of the middle element is approximately the average of the other two: (7 + 39)/2 = 46/2 = 23, which matches sodium's atomic mass.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The average of the first and third elements gives the approximate atomic mass of the middle element: (7 + 39)/2 = 23. The other values don't follow this calculation.

questions.question_text: The bond formed between Na (EN = 0.9) and Cl (EN = 3.0) is primarily:
questions.explanation_correct: The electronegativity difference between Na and Cl is 3.0 − 0.9 = 2.1, which is greater than 1.7. A large electronegativity difference indicates an ionic bond. NaCl is a classic example of an ionic compound.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Covalent bonds form when EN difference is 0. Polar covalent bonds form when EN difference is between 0.4 and 1.7. Metallic bonds occur between metal atoms only.

questions.question_text: The valence shell electronic configuration ns² np⁴ corresponds to which group?
questions.explanation_correct: The configuration ns² np⁴ has 6 valence electrons. For p-block elements, the group number = 10 + number of valence electrons = 10 + 6 = 16. Group 16 includes O, S, Se, Te, and Po (chalcogens).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Group 14 has ns² np² (4 valence electrons). Group 15 has ns² np³ (5 valence electrons). Group 17 has ns² np⁵ (7 valence electrons).
